tv.source-info-name: Pluto TV Space guide by TV

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Gold Basin
programme.desc: In 1995, Professor Jim Kriegh discovered a field of of ancient stone meteorites; the Gold Basin Meteorite is known as the best mapped strewn field in history. In this episode, Geoff and Steve get exclusive access to hunt meteorites in uncharted areas.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Buzzard Coulee & Whitecourt Crater
programme.desc: In Canada, Geoff and search for pieces of the Buzzard Coulee Meteorite. Also, the meteorite hunters receive a surprise invitation to visit the newly discovered, and highly protected, Whitecourt Crater and hunt the surrounding area.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Dry Lake Bed
programme.desc: Dry lake beds are a great place to find never before discovered meteorites. In this episode, the terrain of the bed provides spectacular visuals and high-speed action as Geoff and Steve cover as much ground as possible, looking for dark rocks.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Kansas: Return To Alpha
programme.desc: Geoff and Steve return to their confidential "Alpha" site. During a research and development visit to Orange County Choppers, they help plan a meteorite hunting motorcycle, which is delivered to them by American Chopper star Paul Senior.

programme.title: The New Frontier: The Moons of Olympis
programme.desc: These are the the Moon's of the gas giants. Each a unique and mysterious world of its own. Some have oceans of water, geysers of Sulphur or atmospheres of plastic.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Set Course For Heart of the Sun
programme.desc: NASA’S Parker Solar Probe Mission is on its way and will be shortly followed by Europe’s Solar probe Mission.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Interface
programme.desc: The Ionisphere, where the Earth interfaces with space, is little understood, it effects radio communications, GPS signals and satellites alike.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Stars Above
programme.desc: Stars are a bit like human beings. They can be warm or cold, they come in all kinds of shapes and sizes.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Proving Einstein
programme.desc: Some of the proof of Einstein’s theories had long been elusive, beyond the capabilities of technology, until now.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Emissaries
programme.desc: Our solar system is vast, from our own star the Sun to Earth is nearly 150 million kilometers or 1 Astronomical Unit.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Atmosphere
programme.desc: How do astronauts cope with living in space?

programme.title: The New Frontier: Planet X
programme.desc: The New Horizons mission continues deeper into space, it’s next target looming close.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Tickets Please
programme.desc: No spacecraft have traveled so fast or so close to a star before. It is hoped to reveal the source of the solar winds that effect us here on Earth

programme.title: The New Frontier: The Inner Worlds
programme.desc: They orbit between us and our Star, the inner worlds; hidden within the sun's glare often only visible at sunrise or sunset.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Vesta Unveiled
programme.desc: With the Dawn missions exploration of the asteroid Vesta and the dwarf planet Ceres, asteroids are a hot topic. See what these incredible missions have uncovered.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Virtual Universe
programme.desc: Our understanding of the cosmos is limited by the amount of time we have to see it. Fortunately, computer simulations can help us see how galaxies interact over millions of years, and even how dark matter structures the universe.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Stargazer's Paradise
programme.desc: The Atacama desert is a perfect place for watching the night sky. With still winds and only a handful of cloudy nights each year, it allows scientists to get the absolute most out of their tools.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hubble's Renaissance
programme.desc: Before we can reach space, we must first be able to see it. Hundreds of years ago, the simple telescope was used to give us a seemingly closer vantage. Today, we use the awe-inspiring, and super powerful, Hubble Space Telescope.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Milky Way
programme.desc: This episode traces our view of the Milky Way, from the mythology of ancient sky watchers to the efforts of scientists to map it from the inside out.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Seasons of Saturn
programme.desc: Saturn is the second largest planet and has an astonishing 60 moons in its orbit. Thanks to the Cassini mission, it's also one of the most studied and most photographed planets in our neighborhood.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.
